qas.question: Is the structure of hardwood simple or complex?
What handles most of the water conduction in hardwoods?
Are the vessels in chestnut wood large or small?
In wood from a willow tree, what would you need to use to see the tiny vessels?
Besides ring-porous, what's the other class hardwoods are often divided into?

context: The structure of hardwoods is more <a0_0>complex<a0_0/>. The water conducting capability is mostly taken care of by <a1_0>vessels<a1_0/>: in some cases (oak, chestnut, ash) these are quite <a2_0>large<a2_0/> and distinct, in others (buckeye, poplar, willow) too small to be seen without <a3_0>a hand lens<a3_0/>. In discussing such woods it is customary to divide them into two large classes, ring-porous and <a4_0>diffuse-porous<a4_0/>.
